By BA Rentals Team·Updated February 2026
North Buenos Aires
9/10

Recoleta

Buenos Aires' most elegant neighborhood — French architecture, embassy-lined streets, and the safest area in the city. The choice for families, retirees, and anyone seeking upscale living with European sophistication.

$1,200–$2,200
Monthly Rent
Excellent
Safety
Excellent
Transport
Excellent
Food Scene

Living in Recoleta

Recoleta is the Buenos Aires neighborhood that feels most like Paris. The wide, tree-lined avenues are flanked by ornate Belle Époque buildings, and the streets around the famous Recoleta Cemetery are immaculate. This is where Argentina's old money lives, and the neighborhood has a refined, cultured atmosphere that's quite different from the bohemian energy of Palermo.

For expats, Recoleta offers unmatched safety — it consistently ranks as the safest neighborhood in the city. The embassy district means private security is omnipresent, streets are well-lit, and the general atmosphere feels secure even late at night. The cultural offerings are exceptional: MALBA and the Bellas Artes museum are within walking distance, and the weekend craft fair outside the cemetery draws thousands.

The food scene is more traditional than Palermo — think classic porteño cafes, French-influenced restaurants, and old-school parrillas. You'll find fewer trendy brunch spots but more establishments with decades of history. Rents are high but you get more space than Palermo — large apartments with balconies and high ceilings are common in the classic buildings.

Recoleta

What expats say about recoleta

“Recoleta reminds me of Madrid's Salamanca district. Safe, elegant, everything works. I walk everywhere, even at night. The museums and cafes keep me busy. Perfect for my retirement.”

E

Elena

Retiree · From Spain

“Moved here with our two kids for a year. The safety factor was everything for us. Kids can play in the parks, walk to school. It's expensive but you get what you pay for.”

D

David & Maria

Family with kids · From USA

At a Glance

Monthly Budget
$2,200–$3,800

Including rent, food, transport, and entertainment

Public Transport
Subte Lines:
  • H (Las Heras)
  • D (Pueyrredón)
Lifestyle
WalkabilityExcellent
NightlifeModerate
Green SpacesAbundant
Food SceneExcellent
Coffee & Coworking

Coffee: Many classic cafes (La Biela, Rodi Bar)

Coworking: 3-4 spaces, fewer than Palermo

Key Facts
Population DensityMedium-High
Average Age30-60
Crime RateLowest in BA
ArchitectureBelle Époque / French

Who Should Live Here?

Best For
  • Families
  • Retirees
  • Safety-conscious expats
  • Culture lovers
  • Long-term residents
Not Ideal For
  • Budget travelers
  • Nightlife seekers
  • Young backpackers

Highlights

  • Safest neighborhood in Buenos Aires
  • Beautiful French architecture
  • World-class museums (MALBA, Bellas Artes)
  • Large apartments with classic details
  • Weekend craft fair at the cemetery
  • Embassy district security

Considerations

  • High rent prices
  • Can feel stuffy or overly formal
  • Limited nightlife scene
  • More conservative atmosphere
  • Tourist-heavy around the cemetery

Notable Landmarks

Cementerio de la RecoletaMuseo de Bellas ArtesMALBAFacultad de DerechoFloralis Genérica

Nearby Neighborhoods

Palermo Botánico
9/10
$1,200–$2,000Very Good

The quietest corner of Palermo — centered around the Botanical Garden and Japanese Garden. All the benefits of the Palermo location with a fraction of the noise.

Barrio Norte
7/10
$800–$1,400Very Good

A central, well-connected area straddling the border of Recoleta and Retiro. Classic Buenos Aires apartments, excellent transport, and a convenient location for everything.
